content.question: In an experiment to study collisions, block <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is moving speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when it collides with block <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> which is initially at rest. After the collision, the blocks stick together and move off with speed <math alttext="v sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. For a series of collisions, block <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is given different initial velocities. The graph of <math alttext="v sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown. How would doubling mass <math alttext="m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> change the graph?

choices.label: The slope of the graph line would be less.
The slope of the graph line would be greater.
The graph line would no longer be linear.
There would be no effect on the graph.

The change cannot be determined without knowing the ratio of <math alttext="m sub 1 over m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The slope of the graph line would be greater.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
